titlePart.text: INVESTIGATING CHEMICAL OR PHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF MATERIALS
titlePart.entryReference: apparatus fully provided for in a single other sub-class, see the relevant sub-class, e.g.
separating components of materials in general , , ,
measuring or testing involving enzymes or micro-organisms ,
investigation of foundation soil in situ
sensing humidity changes for compensating measurements of other variables or for compensating readings of instruments for variations in humidity, see or relevant sub-class for variable measured
testing or determining the properties of structures
measuring or investigating electric or magnetic properties of materials
determining sensitivity, graininess, or density of photographic materials
testing component parts of nuclear reactors

noteParagraph.text: Attention is drawn to the notes immediately following the class title ().
In this sub-class, the term "investigating" means testing or determining, and the term "materials" includes solid, liquid, and gaseous media, e.g. the atmosphere.

titlePart.entryReference: obtaining samples of soil or well fluids

titlePart.text: in the solid state, e.g. by cutting
providing a thin slice, e.g. microtome
involving an extracting tool, e.g. core bit
in the liquid or fluent state
with provision for intake at several levels
with provision for splitting samples into portions
with provision for intake from several spaces

titlePart.entryReference: means for supporting the objects or the materials to be analysed in electron microscopes

titlePart.text: Investigating strength properties of solid materials by application of mechanical stress

noteParagraph.text: This group includes the stressing of materials not only below but also beyond the elastic limit, e.g. until breaking occurs.

titlePart.text: Special adaptations of indicating or recording means
titlePart.entryReference: indicating or recording means for measuring in general

titlePart.text: by applying steady tensile or compressive forces
generated by pneumatic or hydraulic pressure
generated by dead weight, e.g. pendulum
Performing tests at high or low temperatures
Investigating ductility, e.g. suitability of sheet metal for deep-drawing or spinning
by applying a single impulsive force, e.g. by falling weight
by applying repeated or pulsating forces
titlePart.entryReference: generation of such forces in general, see such classes or sub-classes as , ,

titlePart.text: generated by mechanical means, e.g. hammer blows
generated by pneumatic or hydraulic means
by performing impressions under a steady load by indentors, e.g. sphere, pyramid
the indentors being put under a minor load and a subsequent major load, i.e. Rockwell system
the indentors performing a scratching movement
by performing impressions under impulsive load by indentors, e.g. falling ball
by measuring rolling friction, e.g. by rocking pendulum
by measuring extent of rebound of a striking body
Performing tests at high or low temperatures
Investigating resistance to wear or abrasion
Investigating the cutting ability of tools
Investigating resistance of materials, e.g. refractory materials, to rapid heat changes
Manufacturing, calibrating, or repairing devices used in investigations covered by the preceding sub-groups
Analysing materials by weighing, e.g. weighing small particles separated from a gas or liquid
by absorbing or adsorbing components of a material and determining change of weight of the adsorbent, e.g. determining moisture content
by removing a component, e.g. by evaporation, and weighing the remainder
Analysing materials by measuring the pressure or volume of a gas or vapour
by absorption, adsorption, or combustion of components and measurement of the change in pressure or volume of the remainder
by combustion followed by absorption or adsorption of the combustion products
by allowing diffusion of components through a porous wall and measuring a pressure or volume difference
the diffusion being followed by combustion or catalytic oxidation
by allowing the material to emit a gas or vapour, e.g. water vapour, and measuring a pressure or volume difference
by allowing the material to react
Investigating density or specific gravity of materials
Analysing materials by determining density or specific gravity
by measuring weight of a known volume
with continuous circulation through a pivotally-supported member
by measuring buoyant force of solid materials by weighing both in air and in a liquid
by observing bodies wholly or partially immersed in fluid materials
by observing the depth of immersion of the bodies, e.g. hydrometers
the body being built into a container
Special adaptations for indicating, recording, or control
by balancing the weight of the bodies
with continuous circulation of the fluid
by observing the transmission of wave or particle radiation through the material
by measuring the blowing pressure of gas bubbles escaping from nozzles at different depths in a liquid
by using flow properties of fluids, e.g. flow through tubes or apertures
by using elements moving through the fluid, e.g. vane
Analysing materials by measuring the density or specific gravity, e.g. determining quantity of moisture
Investigating flow properties of materials, e.g. viscosity, plasticity
Analysing materials by determining flow properties
by measuring flow of the material
through a restricted passage, e.g. tube, aperture
by timing the outflow of a known quantity
by measuring pressure required to produce a known flow
by moving a body within the material
by measuring rising or falling speed of the body
by measuring penetration of wedged gauges
by using rotary bodies, e.g. vane
by measuring damping effect upon oscillatory body
Investigating surface or boundary effects, e.g. wetting power
Analysing materials by determining surface, boundary, or diffusion effects
Investigating permeability, pore-volume, or surface-area of porous materials
Analysing materials by determining these properties
Investigating particle size or size distribution
Investigating number of individual particles suspended in a flowing stream, e.g. Coulter counters
Investigating permeability, pore volume, or surface area of porous materials
Investigating resistance of materials to the weather, to corrosion, or to light
Measuring coefficient of friction between materials
Measuring adhesive force between materials, e.g. of sealing tape, of coating
Investigating by removing material, e.g. spark-testing
Detecting presence of flaws or irregularities
titlePart.entryReference: measuring roughness or irregularity of surfaces

titlePart.text: Measuring moisture content, e.g. by measuring change in length of hygroscopic filament
Investigating or analysing materials by the use of optical means, i.e. using infra-red, visible, or ultra-violet light
Arrangements or apparatus for facilitating the optical investigation
adapted to resist hostile environments or corrosive or abrasive materials
Moving of cuvettes or solid samples to or from the investigating station
Preventing contamination of the components of the optical system or obstruction of the light path
Systems in which incident light is modified in accordance with the properties of the material investigated
titlePart.entryReference: where the material investigated is optically excited causing a change in wavelength of the incident light

titlePart.text: Spectral properties, i.e. comparison of effect of material on the light at two or more different wavelengths or wavelength bands
investigating relative effect of material at wavelengths characteristic of specific elements or molecules, e.g. atomic absorption spectrometry
Phase-affecting properties, e.g. optical path length
inside a container, e.g. in an ampoule
within a flowing fluid, e.g. smoke
Systems in which the material investigated is excited whereby it emits light or causes a change in wavelength of the incident light
using flameless atomising, e.g. graphite furnaces
Systems in which material is subjected to a chemical reaction, the progress or the result of the reaction being investigated
titlePart.entryReference: systems in which material is burnt in a flame or plasma ,

titlePart.text: by observing the effect on a chemical indicator
Systems specially adapted for particular applications
Investigating moving fluids or granular solids
Investigating the presence of flaws or contamination
in moving material, e.g. paper, textiles
in a container or its contents
using penetration of dyes, e.g. fluorescent ink
Investigating or analysing materials by the use of microwaves
Investigating or analysing materials by the use of wave or particle radiation not covered by group or , e.g. X-rays, neutrons
titlePart.entryReference: introducing objects or materials into nuclear reactors, or removing them therefrom, or storing them after treatment therein
construction or operation of X-ray apparatus or circuits therefor

titlePart.text: by transmitting the radiation through the material
the material being confined in a container
the material being a flowing fluid or a flowing granular solid
specially adapted for controlling or monitoring operations or for signalling
the material being a moving sheet
by using diffraction of the radiation, e.g. for investigating crystal structure
by using reflection of the radiation
by means of diffractometry using detectors, e.g. using an analysing crystal or a crystal to be analysed in a central position and one or more displaceable detectors in circumferential positions
titlePart.entryReference: spectrometry of detected or measured radiation intensity

titlePart.text: by irradiating the sample with X-rays and by measuring X-ray fluorescence

titlePart.entryReference: electron or ion-beam tubes for microprobe analysis

titlePart.text: by measuring photoelectric effect, e.g. Auger electrons
Investigating or analysing materials by the use of nuclear magnetic resonance, electron paramagnetic resonance or other spin effects
Generation, homogenisation or stabilisation of magnetic fields
Investigating or analysing materials by the use of thermal means
by investigating changes of state or changes of phase
Analysis by measuring change of freezing point
Analysis by measuring change of boiling point
by using distillation, extraction, sublimation, condensation, freezing, or crystallisation
by investigating thermal coefficient of expansion

titlePart.entryReference: by measuring change of resistance of an electrically-heated body

titlePart.text: by investigating the development of heat, i.e. calorimetry, e.g. by measuring specific heat, by measuring thermal conductivity
on combustion or catalytic oxidation, e.g. of components of gas mixtures
using combustion tubes, e.g. for micro-analysis
using combustion with oxygen under pressure, e.g. in bomb calorimeter
the rise in temperature of the gases resulting from combustion being measured directly
using mechanical temperature-responsive elements, e.g. bimetallic
for investigating the composition of gas mixtures
using the melting or combustion of a solid
the heat developed being transferred to a flowing fluid
the heat developed being transferred to a fixed quantity of fluid
for investigating the composition of gas mixtures
on solution, sorption, or a chemical reaction not involving combustion or catalytic oxidation
by measuring changes of properties of the material due to heat, cold, or expansion
for determining the wetness of steam
by psychrometric means, e.g. wet-and-dry-bulb thermometers
by varying the temperature of a condensing surface
by varying the temperature of the material, e.g. by compression, by expansion
Investigating or analysing materials by the use of electric, electro-chemical, or magnetic means
titlePart.entryReference: measurement or testing of electric or magnetic variables or of electric or magnetic properties of materials

titlePart.text: Investigation or analysis specially adapted for controlling or monitoring operations or for signalling
of a solid body in dependence upon absorption of a fluid
of a solid body in dependence upon reaction with a fluid
of an electrically-heated body in dependence upon change of temperature
caused by burning or catalytic oxidation of surrounding material to be tested, e.g. of gas
caused by changes in the thermal conductivity of a surrounding material to be tested

titlePart.entryReference: electrochemical processes or apparatus in general

titlePart.text: by measuring deposition or liberation of materials from an electrolyte
Coulometry, i.e. measuring coulomb-equivalent of material in an electrolyte
using electrolysis to generate a reagent, e.g. for titration
by measuring currents or voltages in voltaic cells
Polarography, i.e. measuring changes in current under a slowly-varying voltage
due to effect at an electrode
due to effect in the electrolyte, e.g. for pH measurement
by investigating the ionisation of gases
by investigating electric discharges, e.g. emission of cathode
using wave or particle radiation to ionise a gas, e.g. in an ionisation chamber
using electric discharge to ionise a gas
for investigating mechanical hardness, e.g. by investigating saturation or remanence of ferromagnetic material
for investigating the presence of flaws
by applying magnetic powder or magnetic ink

titlePart.entryReference: testing of articles or specimens of solids or fluids for dielectric strength or breakdown voltage

titlePart.text: Investigating or analysing materials by the use of sonic or ultrasonic vibrations
Investigating or analysing non-biological materials by the use of the chemical methods specified in the sub-groups
titlePart.entryReference: measuring or testing processes involving enzymes or micro-organisms

titlePart.text: Apparatus specially adapted for such methods

noteParagraph.text: The observation of the progress of the reactions specified below by any of the methods specified in groups , if this is of major importance, is dealt with in the group concerned.

titlePart.text: Investigating or analysing materials by specific methods not covered by the preceding groups
titlePart.entryReference: measuring or testing processes involving enzymes or micro-organisms

titlePart.text: Determining fat content, e.g. by butyrometer

titlePart.entryReference: determining the germinating capacity of seeds

titlePart.text: Chemical analysis of biological material, e.g. blood, urine
Testing involving biospecific ligand binding methods

titlePart.entryReference: measuring or testing processes involving enzymes or micro-organisms, compositions or test papers therefore
processes of forming such compositions, condition responsive control in microbiological or enzymological processes

noteParagraph.text: The term "involving", when used in relation to a material, includes the testing for the material as well as employing the material as a determinant or reactant in a test for a different material.
In groups , in the absence of an indication to the contrary, an invention is classified in the last appropriate place.

titlePart.text: Use of compounds or compositions for colorimetric, spectrophotometric or fluorometric investigation, e.g. use of reagent paper
involving proteins, peptides or amino acids
involving blood pigments, e.g. hemoglobin, bilirubin
involving blood groups or blood types
involving iron binding capacity of blood
involving blood or serum control standard
Automatic analysis not limited to methods or materials provided for in a single one of the preceding groups
using a plurality of sample containers moved by a conveyor system past one or more treatment or analysis stations
using a stream of discrete samples flowing along a tube system
Details not covered by any preceding group
